details.title: Toward an efficient implementation of the MOCUS algorithm

authors.affiliation: LaBRI, Univ. Bordeaux I, Talence, France

p: Antoine Rauzy is with the French National Center for Scientific Research (CNRS) and the Instut de Mathé,toqie de Luminy. His topics of interest are formal methods and reliability engineering. His background is in computer science (Ph.D., Habilitation à Diriger des Recherches).

authors.name: A. Rauzy

details.abstract: MOCUS is probably the most famous algorithm to compute minimal cutsets of fault trees. It was proposed by Fussell and Vesely in 1972. It is now the core method of many fault-tree assessment tools. Despite its wide use, textbooks and articles give very few details about how to implement it. This paper describes data structures as well as several improvements and heuristics that make MOCUS very efficient. Experiments on a benchmark of the 1819 event-tree sequences that were generated during a PSA study are reported. Advantages and drawbacks of MOCUS and Binary Decision Diagrams are discussed.

references.title: A new methodology for obtaining cut sets for fault trees

context.text: MOCUS is probably the most famous algorithm to compute minimal cutsets of fault trees, event trees, block diagrams, etc.; it was proposed in [1].

references.text: J. B. Fussell, W. E. Vesely, "A new methodology for obtaining cut sets for fault trees", Trans. Amer. Nucl. Soc., vol. 15, pp. 262-263, Jun. 1972.

references.title: RISK SPECTRUM, Theory Manual

context.text: It is now the core method of many fault-tree assessment tools, including Risk Spectrum [2] and IRRAS (SAPHIRE) [3] that are both widely used by in nuclear engineering.
Most authors (e.g., [2], [3]) suggest expanding \$k\$-out-of-\$n\$ gates as a sum of products.

references.text: U. Berg, RISK SPECTRUM Theory Manual, 1994, RELCON Teknik AB.

references.title: Fault tree reduction and quantification&#821And overview of IRRAS algorithms

context.text: It is now the core method of many fault-tree assessment tools, including Risk Spectrum [2] and IRRAS (SAPHIRE) [3] that are both widely used by in nuclear engineering.
Most authors (e.g., [2], [3]) suggest expanding \$k\$-out-of-\$n\$ gates as a sum of products.
Such simplifications are described in [3], et al.
This was noticed by several authors, e.g., [3].

references.text: K. D. Russel, D. M. Rasmuson, "Fault tree reduction and quantification̵And overview of IRRAS algorithms", Reliab. Eng. Syst. Saf., vol. 40, pp. 149-164, 1993.

references.title: Fault tree analysis:

context.text: During 1990's, the framework of fault tree assessment algorithms has been deeply impacted by the introduction of BDD based methods (see [4], [5] for the very first contributions).

links.abstract: The performances of almost all available fault tree analysis tools are limited by the performance of the prime implicant computation procedure used. All these products manipulate the prime implicants of the fault trees explicitly, so that their complexities are directly related to the number of prime implicants to be generated. The authors present a novel analysis method of coherent as well as noncoherent fault trees that overcomes this limitation because its computational cost is not related to...

references.text: O. Coudert, J.-C. Madre, " Fault tree analysis: \$10^{20}\$ prime implicants and beyond ", Proc. Ann. Reliability and Maintainability Symp., 1993.

references.title: New algorithms for fault tree analysis

context.text: During 1990's, the framework of fault tree assessment algorithms has been deeply impacted by the introduction of BDD based methods (see [4], [5] for the very first contributions).

references.text: A. Rauzy, "New algorithms for fault tree analysis", Reliab. Eng. Syst. Saf., vol. 5, no. 59, pp. 203-211, 1993.

references.title: Graph based algorithms for Boolean function manipulation

context.text: BDD [6], [7] are the state-of-the-art data structure to encode and to manipulate Boolean functions.

links.abstract: In this paper we present a new data structure for representing Boolean functions and an associated set of manipulation algorithms. Functions are represented by directed, acyclic graphs in a manner similar to the representations introduced by Lee [1] and Akers [2], but with further restrictions on the ordering of decision variables in the graph. Although a function requires, in the worst case, a graph of size exponential in the number of arguments, many of the functions encountered in typical app...

references.text: R. Bryant, "Graph based algorithms for Boolean function manipulation", IEEE Trans. Comp., vol. 35, no. 8, pp. 677-691, Aug. 1986.

references.title: Efficient implementation of a BDD package

context.text: BDD [6], [7] are the state-of-the-art data structure to encode and to manipulate Boolean functions.

links.abstract: Efficient manipulation of Boolean functions is an important component of many computer-aided design tasks. A package for manipulating Boolean functions based on the reduced, ordered, binary decision diagram (ROBDD) representation is described. The package is based on an efficient implementation of the if-then-else (ITE) operator. A hash table is used to maintain a strong canonical form in the ROBDD and memory use is improved by merging the hash table and the ROBDD into a hybrid data structure. A...

references.text: K. Brace, R. Rudell, R. Bryant, "Efficient implementation of a BDD package" in Proc. 27th ACM/IEEE Design Automation Conf., pp. 40-45, 1990, IEEE 0738.

references.title: Mathematical foundation of minimal cutsets

context.text: The difficulty is that, conversely to MOCUS-like algorithms, the BDD technology does not easily support approximations (although some progress has been made recently in this direction [8]).
[8] has an algebraic framework for the notion of minimal cutsets.

links.abstract: Since their introduction in the reliability field, binary decision diagrams have proved to be the most efficient tool to assess Boolean models such as fault trees. Their success increases the need of sound mathematical foundations for the notions that are involved in reliability and dependability studies. This paper clarifies the mathematical status of the notion of minimal cutsets which have a central role in fault-tree assessment. Algorithmic issues are discussed. Minimal cutsets are distinct ...

references.text: A. Rauzy, "Mathematical foundation of minimal cutsets", IEEE Trans. Rel., vol. 50, no. 4, pp. 389, Dec. 2001.

references.title: How to hand-calculate system reliability characteristics

context.text: The contribution is sometimes called the Fussell–Vesely importance factor of \$\rho\$ because it was proposed by them [9] as a risk-ranking measure.

links.abstract: A simple method is given for calculating a) reliability characteristics of repairable and nonrepairable systems, and b) the importance of the individual system components. Assumptions made include independent component failures and constant failure and repair rates for the components. The methods can easily be implemented in a computer program that would be inexpensive to execute and would always overpredict (usually very slightly) the system failure characteristics.

references.text: J. B. Fussel, "How to hand-calculate system reliability characteristics", IEEE Trans. Rel., vol. R-24, no. 3, 1975.

references.title: Zero-suppressed BDDs for set manipulation in combinatorial problems

context.text: Minato's “Zero-Suppressed BDD” [10] are a potential candidate to do the job.

references.text: S. Minato, "Zero-suppressed BDDs for set manipulation in combinatorial problems", Proc. 30th ACM/IEEE Design Automation Conf., pp. 272-277, 1993.

references.title: Mathematical Theory of Reliability of Time Dependent Systems With Practical Applications

context.text: The book [11] proposes 12 transformations to simplify the formulae.

references.text: I. N. Kovalenko, N. Y. Kuznetsov, P. A. Pegg, Mathematical Theory of Reliability of Time Dependent Systems With Practical Applications, 1997, ISBN 0-471-95&#820060-2.

references.title: IEEE Trans. Rel.

context.text: These transformations are used by the FAMOCUTN algorithm [12].

links.abstract: The paper describes the principal difficulties arising with cutset evaluation for large fault trees containing many replicated gates and events. The usual bottom-up algorithms based on the usual modularization technique with truncation of low-probability cutsets can lead to great computer-tine expenditures with a large upper bound for the probability of the system failure due to the truncated cutsets (truncation error). This paper presents a new method for multi-level representation of fault tre...

references.text: W. Hennings, N. Kuznetsov, IEEE Trans. Rel., vol. 44, no. 3, pp. 368-376, Sep. 1995.

references.title: Modules of coherent binary systems

context.text: The notion of module was introduced in [13].

references.text: Z. W. Birnbaum, J. P. Esary, "Modules of coherent binary systems", SIAM J. Appl. Math., vol. 13, pp. 442-462, 1965.

references.title: A linear time algorithm to find modules of fault trees

context.text: Modules already present in the formula can be detected in linear time [14].

links.abstract: A module of a fault tree is a subtree whose terminal events do not occur elsewhere in the tree. Modules, which are independent subtrees, can be used to reduce the computational cost of basic operations on fault trees, such as the computation of the probability of the root event or the computation of the minimal cut sets. This paper presents a linear time algorithm to detect modules of a fault tree, coherent or not, that is derived from the Tarjan algorithm to find strongly connected components o...

references.text: Y. Dutuit, A. Rauzy, "A linear time algorithm to find modules of fault trees", IEEE Trans. Rel., vol. 45, no. 3, pp. 422-425, 1996.

references.title: On simplification of large fault trees

context.text: [15]suggests a promising rewriting technique based on propagation of variable values.

references.text: I. Niemelä (Niemela), "On simplification of large fault trees", Reliab. Eng. Syst. Saf., vol. 44, pp. 135-138, 1994.

references.title: An improved top-down algorithm combined with modularization as highly efficient method for fault tree analysis

context.text: For heuristic #2, [16]suggests developing first the gate with the greatest number of basic events as arguments.
Except in [16], the order in which top-down algorithms consider the products, and the variables inside the products, is not discussed in literature.

references.text: L. Camarinopoulos, J. Yllera, "An improved top-down algorithm combined with modularization as highly efficient method for fault tree analysis", Reliab. Eng. Syst. Saf., vol. 11, pp. 93-108, 1985.

context.text: An event-tree sequence is assimilated with the conjunct of success and failure branches that appear along the sequence [17].

patentCitations.patentAbstract: The present invention is a fault tree analysis system, comprising: k/n conjunction weeding means for weeding a conjunction including disjoint basic k/n gates and/or disjoint simple k/n gates and removing the conjunction if its order is greater than a given maximal order of minimal cut sets.
patentCitations.title: Fault tree analysis system, fault tree analysis method and programme

patentCitations.patentAbstract: The present invention is a fault tree system reliability analysis system, comprising: k/n gate splitting means for splitting a disjunctive k/n gate with inputs of OR gates into disjoint conjunctive k/m gates (m?n) without input of OR gate.
patentCitations.title: Fault tree system reliability analysis system, fault tree system reliability analysis method, and program therefor
